stem: The infection control nurse is reviewing the serology profiles for four clients. Based on the documentation in the Serology Profile, match each finding with the correct clinical status.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 24y/o male recently exposed to Hep B via a needle stick; currently asymptomatic. 
Patient 2: 30y/o female, health care student who completed the Hep B vaccine series last month. 
Patient 3: 45y/o male with chronic jaundice and fatigue for 6 months. 
Patient 4: 28y/o female who had Hep A as a child and is now fully recovered.

tabs.title: Serology Profile
tabs.content:
PatientPositive MarkerNegative Marker
Patient 1HBsAg (Surface Antigen)Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody)
Patient 2Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody)HBsAg (Surface Antigen)
Patient 3HBsAg and HBeAgNo antibodies detected
Patient 4IgG anti-HAVIgM anti-HAV

tabs.title: Liver Function Tests
tabs.content:
Patient 3: ALT 850 U/L, AST 720 U/L. 
Patient 1, 2, 4: ALT/AST within normal limits.

rationale.correct: Antigen positive (Ag) means the virus is present (Infectious/Acute) (r1). Antibody positive (Anti-) generally means the body has fought it or been vaccinated. If ONLY the Surface Antibody (Anti-HBs) is positive (r2), the patient is **Immune via Vaccination**. If IgG is positive (r4) but IgM is negative, the infection is in the past (Immune via infection). IgM (r3) is 'Immediate' (Acute).
clinicalPearls: HBsAg: S = Surface. If you HAVE the surface, you HAVE the virus.
Anti-HBs: S = Saved. You are saved (Immune).
IgM = M for Misery (Active/Acute). IgG = G for Gone (Past Infection).

questionTrap.trap: Thinking a positive antibody always means vaccination.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the Core Antibody (Anti-HBc). If positive, they had the disease. If negative and Anti-HBs is positive, they are immune via vaccine.
